Diagnosis:	Transverse colon adenocarcinoma, pT2N0M0
	Laparoscopic extended right hemicolectomy 15 March 2024
	Histology: Moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, MSS, PIK3CA H1047R mutation detected
?
[redacted name] is a 62-year-old gentleman who has recently undergone surgery for stage II colon cancer. He was diagnosed following investigation of iron deficiency anaemia picked up on routine blood tests. Colonoscopy on 1 March 2024 identified a 4cm transverse colon mass, biopsies confirming adenocarcinoma.
?
He underwent uncomplicated laparoscopic extended right hemicolectomy on 15/3/24. Final histology showed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with invasion into but not through the muscularis propria. All 18 lymph nodes were negative. No lymphovascular invasion was identified. Molecular testing shows microsatellite stable disease with PIK3CA H1047R mutation.
?
In his past medical history, he has well-controlled hypertension on amlodipine. He takes no other regular medications and has no drug allergies. He is an ex-smoker having quit 15 years ago and drinks minimal alcohol.
?
He has recovered well from surgery with return to normal bowel function and good energy levels. His wound sites have healed well. Performance status is 0.
?
I have discussed his case with him today. Given the pathological staging and absence of high-risk features, adjuvant chemotherapy is not indicated. The standard of care would be clinical follow-up with regular CEA monitoring and CT surveillance according to our local protocol. I have provided written information about follow-up care and symptoms to watch for.
?
The plan is to arrange baseline CT chest/abdomen/pelvis and see him again in 3 months with the results. CEA monitoring will be arranged through our nurse-led telephone clinic.
